item.title: Rain Drops: Condensation and Acceleration
item.description: Problem Solution Problem Problem 49, page 189 in Simmons (2016) Newtonâ€™s second law of motion \[ F = ma = m \frac{dv}{dt} \] can be written in the form \[ \begin{equation} F = \frac{d \left( mv \right)}{dt} \tag{1} \label{momentum-rate} \end{equation} \] in terms of the momentum \(mv\) of a particle of mass \(m\) and velocity \(v\), and remains valid even if \(m\) is not constant. A spherical raindrop falls through air with water vapor, and assume that by condensation the mass of the raindrop increases at a rate proportional to its surface area, with \(c\) the constant of proportionality.

item.title: Deriving the Quotient Rule from the Product Rule
item.description: From Product to Quotient Product Rule of Differentiation Quotient Rule of Differentiation Derive the Quotient Rule from the Product Rule Problems Extend the Product Rule and Prove Tangent Lines Intersecting on a Curve Reference From Product to Quotient I have always had a hard time remembering the quotient rule for derivatives. item.title: Tangent Lines and Non-Existent Ones
item.description: Definition of a Tangent Line Slope of a Tangent Line on a Curve Condition for Existence Limit of an Absolute Value Problem Solution Reference Definition of a Tangent Line Consider a curve \(y = f(x)\), and let \(P\) be a given fixed point on this curve. Let \(Q\) be a second nearby point on the curve, and draw the secant line \(PQ\). The tangent line at \(P\) can now be thought of as the limiting position of the variable secant as \(Q\) slides along the curve toward \(P\).
